Accessibility.html:
Overview

Since decorators serve a strictly decorative purpose and not an interactive or functional one, there are very few accessibility rules that surround them. Please note the following rules which do apply.

Resources

Image used as part of page design
Decorative images don’t add information to the content of a page. For example, the information provided by the image might already be given using adjacent text, or the image might be included to make the website more visually attractive. In these cases, a null (empty) alt text should be provided (alt="") so that they can be ignored by assistive technologies, such as screen readers. Text values for these types of images would add audible clutter to screen reader output or could distract users if the topic is different from that in adjacent text. Leaving out the alt attribute is also not an option because when it is not provided, some screen readers will announce the file name of the image instead.

Example

Image used as part of page design
Decorative images don’t add information to the content of a page. For example, the information provided by the image might already be given using adjacent text, or the image might be included to make the website more visually attractive. In these cases, a null (empty) alt text should be provided (alt="") so that they can be ignored by assistive technologies, such as screen readers. Text values for these types of images would add audible clutter to screen reader output or could distract users if the topic is different from that in adjacent text. Leaving out the alt attribute is also not an option because when it is not provided, some screen readers will announce the file name of the image instead.

Example

Horizontal dividers, vertical dividers, markers, and bullets should be treated as images used as part of page design. To ensure that screen readers do not focus on these, make sure to use a null tag.

Example

Horizontal dividers with description do convey meaningful information to the user and should contain an alt tag matching their visible label.

Color Contrast ✅

Since all non-text elements of decorators are not essential to convey information to the user, they are exempt from the non-text contrast requirement of 3:1. For horizontal dividers with description, the description is considered meaningful text and it is not above the “large-scale text threshold” of 18pt, therefore the text must meet a minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1. WCAG References 1.4.3: Contrast (Minimum) (Level AA) 1.4.11: Non-text Contrast (Level AA)

Screen Reader

Only horizontal divider with description should receive a screen reader acknowledgement. For the horizontal divider, you should use aria-labeledby to denote the content

Horizontal divider with description

Functional role and Initial status not applicable

Guideline.html:
Overview

Decorators are non-interactive elements that add visual clarity or separation while minimizing noise or disruption from other elements on the page. Dividers bring clarity to a layout by grouping similar elements and dividing dissimilar elements. They can also be used to establish rhythm and hierarchy.

While decorators contribute less noise than text or images, they still add some noise and serve a limited function. Decorators should be used sparingly and with intention to ensure that they improve a UI and not detract from it.

Use Cases

Illustrate how the component is used and what kinds of use cases the user can expect from this component.

Layout

Example

Purpose

Horizontal divider

Used to separate two vertically stacked sections of a page or content block

Vertical divider

Used to separate two horizontally stacked sections of a page or content block

Horizontal divider with description

Used to separate a vertically stacked section of a page where the lower section requires a label or description

Marker

Used in very specific cases for visual styling applied to only one edge of an object to denote a category (e.g., used on the edge of a calendar block to denote an accepted or tentative invite)

Bullet

Used to separate short text elements that are aligned horizontally

When to use

Use a divider when:
The line is not an integral or structural part of the main component
The line forms an incomplete shape around an object (i.e. the line doesn’t extend all the way across a page or only forms a border on one side of the object)
The line creates a semantic grouping for similar items or a purposeful distinction between dissimilar items

When Not to use

Many Momentum components use strokes to distinguish their spatial boundaries. This serves a similar purpose to horizontal or vertical dividers, but they should not be interchanged for one another. Do not use a divider when: the line is an integral part of the main component (e.g. the rows of a table or the boundary of a breadcrumb bar) the line encloses the entire object

Usage

Chips allow users to enter information, make selections, filter content, or trigger actions. They typically reflect the input a user types in, but can also represent static information.

Chips can be manipulated by editing the text or deleted by clicking on the x. While buttons are expected to appear consistently and with familiar calls to action, chips should appear dynamically as a group of multiple interactive elements.

Types

If there are multiple types of this component, showcase them and demonstrate how they’re different.

Horizontal divider with description

Used to separate a vertically stacked section of a page where the lower section requires a label or description

Marker

Used in very specific cases for visual styling applied to only one edge of an object to denote a category

Bullet

Used to separate short text elements that are aligned horizontally

Behavior

By the inherent nature of decorators, they are not interactive and they should not be used for any situations that require an interaction.

Dos and Dont’s

Horizontal separator vs. Stroke

Use appropriate size for smaller spaces such as card, list menu, input etc.

Make sure the spinners are not too big or too small

Vertical separator vs. Stroke

3 dot loaders are default in the Control Hub Cards component.

Spinners should not replace 3 dot loaders.

Vertical separator vs. Stroke

3 dot loaders are default in the Control Hub Cards component.

Spinners should not replace 3 dot loaders.
